summary: **noun / hi-fi accessory.** A **center-spindle clamp** with a cam-action.
definition: **noun / hi-fi accessory.** A **center-spindle clamp** with a cam-action "reflex" lever that locks the record tight to the platter and flattens dish-warps. Introduced in the 1980s as audiophile turntable manufacturers sought solutions for improved record-to-platter coupling, the reflex clamp uses a spring-loaded cam mechanism that distributes downward pressure evenly across the label area when the lever is engaged. Unlike simple screw-down clamps or static weights, the cam action provides consistent clamping force (typically 3-8 pounds) without requiring precise threading or risking over-tightening. The design excels at flattening minor warps and improving bass response by eliminating air gaps between vinyl and platter mat. High-end models from Michell Engineering, Clearaudio, and J.A. Michell feature machined aluminum or brass construction with dampening properties that reduce resonance transmission. The quick-release lever makes cueing faster than thread-type clamps, though purists debate whether the mechanical complexity introduces micro-vibrations. Essential for warped vintage pressings and maximizing sound quality on high-mass platters, reflex clamps remain popular among audiophiles prioritizing convenience without sacrificing performance, though they require sufficient spindle height clearance and cannot be used with automatic tonearm return mechanisms.
etymology: Named for the "reflex" cam mechanism that springs back when released, term emerged in British hi-fi marketing during the 1980s audiophile boom.
